Weil Conjecture for Curves

Assjock
Algebraic GeometryArithmetic GeometryNumber Theory Algebraic Geometry Number Theory Arithmetic Geometry

发布于：Nov 11, 2024

7.4k words

46 min

宝宝巴士第三集. 把之前的内容重新整合了一下, 配上了Weil对他的猜想在curve 情况下的证明懒得改之前的typo 了:(

Overview

In Weil4, Andre Weil made his remarkable conjecture about the Zeta function over finite field. For any projective variety XXX over finite field Fq\mathbb{F}_{q}Fq​, we denote the set of Fqm\mathbb{F}_{q^{m}}Fqm​ points by X(Fqm)X(\mathbb{F}_{q^{m}})X(Fqm​).

Theorem 1 (Weil-Grothendieck-Deligne). Let Nm=∣X(Fqm)∣N_{m}=\left| X(\mathbb{F}_{q^{m}}) \right|Nm​=∣X(Fqm​)∣ and ZX(t)=exp⁡(∑m≥1Nmmtm)Z_{X}(t)=\exp(\sum\limits_{m\geq 1}\frac{N_{m}}{m}t^{m})ZX​(t)=exp(m≥1∑​mNm​​tm) be the Zeta function of varitey XXX. Assume dim⁡X=n\dim X=ndimX=n.

ZX(t)Z_{X}(t)ZX​(t) is a rational function.

Let E=Δ⋅ΔE=\Delta\cdot \DeltaE=Δ⋅Δ be the self-intersection number of diagonal. Then ZX(t)Z_{X}(t)ZX​(t) satisfies the functional equation

ZX(1qnt)=±qnE/2tEZX(t).Z_{X}(\frac{1}{q^{n}t})=\pm q^{nE /2}t^{E}Z_{X}(t). ZX​(qnt1​)=±qnE/2tEZX​(t).

We can write

ZX(t)=P1(t)⋯P2n−1(t)P0(t)⋯P2n(t)Z_{X}(t)=\frac{P_{1}(t)\cdots P_{2n-1}(t)}{P_{0}(t)\cdots P_{2n}(t)} ZX​(t)=P0​(t)⋯P2n​(t)P1​(t)⋯P2n−1​(t)​

where P0(t)=1−tP_{0}(t)=1-tP0​(t)=1−t, P2n(t)=1−qntP_{2n}(t)=1-q^{n}tP2n​(t)=1−qnt and for 1≤i≤2n−11\leq i\leq 2n-11≤i≤2n−1, Pi(t)P_{i}(t)Pi​(t) is a polynomial with integer coefficients, with roots αij\alpha_{ij}αij​ such that ∣αij∣=qi/2\left| \alpha_{ij} \right| =q^{i /2}∣αij​∣=qi/2.

Define the iii-th betti number Bi(X)=deg⁡Pi(t)B_{i}(X)=\deg P_{i}(t)Bi​(X)=degPi​(t). Then E=∑i(−1)iBiE=\sum\limits_{i}(-1)^{i}B_{i}E=i∑​(−1)iBi​.

The study on Weil conjecture advanced the integration of modern algebraic geometry and number theory. In the 1960s Grothendieck and Dwork used etale cohomology and p-adic analysis proved the rationality part of Weil conjecture. Grothendieck’s work also proved the functional equation part and pointed out the connection between Weil conjecture and cohomology theory. Deligne roved the Riemann Conjecture part in 1971 and was awarded the Fields Prize for his work. In this expository ariticle, we will follow Weil’s idea to prove Theorem 1 in smooth projective curve case.

Degree and Frobenius morphism

The idea of Deligne’s work is reduce Theorem 1 to some cohomology problems, and those NmN_{m}Nm​ are number of fixed points under some automorphism of XXX. First we recall some facts in intersection theory, a quick reference for this is Ha2 Appendix 3. From now on we assume XXX is a nonsingular curve over some field kkk and we first work on X×XX\times XX×X. Denote the intersection product of divisor CCC and DDD by C⋅DC\cdot DC⋅D.

Definition 2. Let L\mathcal{L}L be a line sheaf on XXX. The Hilbert polynomial χ(L(n))\chi(\mathcal{L}(n))χ(L(n)) is a quadratic function α2(L)2n2+α1(L)n+α0(L)\frac{\alpha_{2}(\mathcal{L})}{2}n^{2}+\alpha_{1}(\mathcal{L})n+\alpha_{0}(\mathcal{L})2α2​(L)​n2+α1​(L)n+α0​(L). The degree of L\mathcal{L}L is defined to be α1(L)−α1(OX)\alpha_{1}(\mathcal{L})-\alpha_{1}(\mathcal{O}_{X})α1​(L)−α1​(OX​).

If DDD is a divisor of XXX, by Hirzebruch-Riemann-Roch theorem, D⋅H=deg⁡(OX(D))D\cdot H= \deg(\mathcal{O}_{X}(D))D⋅H=deg(OX​(D)), we define the number be the degree of the divisor DDD. The degree of DDD is a additive function on the divisor group Div(X)\mathrm{Div}(X)Div(X) since the first chern class c1c_{1}c1​ is additive on tensor products.

Definition 3. Let f:X→Yf:X\to Yf:X→Y be a proper morphism of projective varieties. Define the degree of fff be the number [K(X),K(f(X))][K(X),K(f(X))][K(X),K(f(X))]. If dim⁡Y<dim⁡X\dim Y<\dim XdimY<dimX, define the degree be 0.

Using the projection formula in Chow ring f∗(x⋅f∗y)=f∗x⋅yf_{*}(x\cdot f^{*}y)=f_{*}x\cdot yf∗​(x⋅f∗y)=f∗​x⋅y, we can show f∗C⋅f∗D=deg⁡(f)C⋅Df^{*}C\cdot f^{*}D=\deg(f)C\cdot Df∗C⋅f∗D=deg(f)C⋅D. For any line bundle L\mathcal{L}L, deg⁡(f∗L)=deg⁡(f)deg⁡(L)\deg (f^{*}\mathcal{L})=\deg (f)\deg (\mathcal{L})deg(f∗L)=deg(f)deg(L). Note the degree is always a finite number.

We shall also recall some properties of geometric points on a variety XXX. For any point x∈Xx\in Xx∈X, denote the residue field at xxx by k(x)k(x)k(x). The set of X(Fqm)X(\mathbb{F}_{q^{m}})X(Fqm​) points is exactly ∐x∈XHom(k(x),Fqm)\coprod\limits_{x\in X}\mathop{\mathrm{Hom}}(k(x), \mathbb{F}_{q^{m}})x∈X∐​Hom(k(x),Fqm​).

Proposition 4. Let XXX, mmm defined as above, then

∣X(Fqm)∣=∑d∣md⋅∣{x closed point ∣[k(x):Fq]=d}∣\left| X(\mathbb{F}_{q^{m}}) \right|=\sum_{d\mid m} d\cdot \left| \{x \text{ closed point }| [k(x):\mathbb{F}_{q}]=d\} \right| ∣X(Fqm​)∣=d∣m∑​d⋅∣{x closed point ∣[k(x):Fq​]=d}∣

Proof

Proof. First any image of geometric point Spec(Fqm)→X\mathop{\mathrm{Spec}}(\mathbb{F}_{q^{m}})\to XSpec(Fqm​)→X is closed since the extension is algebraic. We act Gal(Fqm/Fq)\mathrm{Gal}(\mathbb{F}_{q^{m}}/\mathbb{F_{q}})Gal(Fqm​/Fq​) on Hom(k(x),Fqm)\mathop{\mathrm{Hom}}(k(x),\mathbb{F}_{q^{m}})Hom(k(x),Fqm​) by composition on the left. Clearly the action is transitive and has stablizer Gal(k(x)/Fq)\mathrm{Gal}(k(x)/\mathbb{F}_{q})Gal(k(x)/Fq​). So ∣Hom(k(x),Fqm)∣=[k(x):Fq]\left| \mathop{\mathrm{Hom}}(k(x),\mathbb{F}_{q^{m}})\right|=[k(x):\mathbb{F}_{q}]∣Hom(k(x),Fqm​)∣=[k(x):Fq​]. ◻

Define the number ∣{x closed point ∣[k(x):Fq]=d}∣\left| \{x \text{ closed point }| [k(x):\mathbb{F}_{q}]=d\} \right|∣{x closed point ∣[k(x):Fq​]=d}∣ to be the degree of closed point xxx. For curve XXX, deg⁡(x)\deg(x)deg(x) is the number of points in Weil divisor ∑σ∈Gal(Fqm/Fq)σ(x)\sum\limits_{\sigma\in \mathrm{Gal}(\mathbb{F}_{q^{m}}/\mathbb{F_{q}})}\sigma(x)σ∈Gal(Fqm​/Fq​)∑​σ(x), i.e. the number of points in the divisor which is stable under the Galois action.

Consider the absolute Frobenius φ:X→X\varphi:X\to Xφ:X→X which is identity map on the underlying topological space and s↦sqs\mapsto s^{q}s↦sq on the structure sheaf. φ\varphiφ is a morphism of Fq\mathbb{F}_{q}Fq​ schemes. It can be represented as an action of Galois group Gal(Fqˉ/Fq)\mathrm{Gal}(\bar{\mathbb{F}_{q}}/\mathbb{F}_{q})Gal(Fq​ˉ​/Fq​):

Definition 5. The Galois group Gal(Fqˉ/Fq)\mathrm{Gal}(\bar{\mathbb{F}_{q}} /\mathbb{F}_{q})Gal(Fq​ˉ​/Fq​) acts on XXX as follows: For each σ∈Gal(Fqˉ/Fq)\sigma\in \mathrm{Gal}(\bar{\mathbb{F}_{q}} /\mathbb{F}_{q})σ∈Gal(Fq​ˉ​/Fq​), φˉ:XFqˉ→XFqˉ\bar{\varphi}:X_{\bar{\mathbb{F}_{q}}}\to X_{\bar{\mathbb{F}_{q}}}φˉ​:XFq​ˉ​​→XFq​ˉ​​ is the fibre product σ×idX\sigma\times id_{X}σ×idX​.

The discussion above also shows that for n∣mn\mid mn∣m, the stablizer of X(Fqm)X(\mathbb{F}_{q^{m}})X(Fqm​) under the Galois group action Gal(Fqm/Fqn)\mathrm{Gal}(\mathbb{F}_{q^{m}}/\mathbb{F}_{q^{n}})Gal(Fqm​/Fqn​) is X(Fqn)X(\mathbb{F}_{q^{n}})X(Fqn​).

Example 6. If we consider an affine variety YYY which admits a closed immersion Y→AFqnY\to \mathbb{A}^{n}_{\mathbb{F}_{q}}Y→AFq​n​. Then the Frobenius action on YFqˉY_{\bar{\mathbb{F}_{q}}}YFq​ˉ​​ can be derived from the Frobenius action on AFqˉn\mathbb{A}^{n}_{\bar{\mathbb{F}_{q}}}AFq​ˉ​n​. In particular, the Frobenius action on AFqˉn\mathbb{A}^{n}_{\bar{\mathbb{F}_{q}}}AFq​ˉ​n​ has the corresponding Fqˉ\bar{\mathbb{F}_{q}}Fq​ˉ​ algebra morphism Fqˉ[x1,…,xn]→Fqˉ[x1,…,xn]\bar{\mathbb{F}_{q}}[x_{1},\dots, x_{n}]\to \bar{\mathbb{F}_{q}}[x_{1},\dots, x_{n}]Fq​ˉ​[x1​,…,xn​]→Fq​ˉ​[x1​,…,xn​] given by a→apa\to a^{p}a→ap on the coefficients. Therefore, the Fqˉ\bar{\mathbb{F}_{q}}Fq​ˉ​ points on YYY has the morphism given by (a1,…,an)↦(a1q,…,anq)(a_{1},\dots, a_{n})\mapsto (a_{1}^{q},\dots, a_{n}^{q})(a1​,…,an​)↦(a1q​,…,anq​).

Lemma 7. Let XXX is reduced kkk-scheme and YYY is separated kkk-scheme. f:X→Yf:X\to Yf:X→Y is a morphism. Let Γf(X)\Gamma_{f}(X)Γf​(X) be the closed subscheme with reduced subscheme structure. Then Γf(X)≅X\Gamma_{f}(X)\cong XΓf​(X)≅X.

Proof

Proof. Note that Γf\Gamma_{f}Γf​ is obtained by pulling back the diagonal:

Δ\DeltaΔ is closed immersion so Γf\Gamma_{f}Γf​ is a closed immersion, hence Γf\Gamma_{f}Γf​ is an isomorphism to the schematic image Γf(X)‾\overline{\Gamma_{f}(X)}Γf​(X)​. Since XXX is reduced, we may factor Γf\Gamma_{f}Γf​ through Γf(X)\Gamma_{f}(X)Γf​(X), which induces an morphism from Γf(X)‾\overline{\Gamma_{f}(X)}Γf​(X)​ to Γf(X)\Gamma_{f}(X)Γf​(X). From the definition of reduced subscheme, Γf(X)‾≅Γf(X)\overline{\Gamma_{f}(X)}\cong \Gamma_{f}(X)Γf​(X)​≅Γf​(X). ◻

Theorem 8. Let Γφ\Gamma_{\varphi}Γφ​ and δ\deltaδ be the graph of φˉ\bar{\varphi}φˉ​ and ididid in XFqˉ×XFqˉX_{\bar{\mathbb{F}_{q}}}\times X_{\bar{\mathbb{F}_{q}}}XFq​ˉ​​×XFq​ˉ​​. The intersection multiplicity Γφ⋅Δ=Nm\Gamma_{\varphi}\cdot \Delta= N_{m}Γφ​⋅Δ=Nm​.

Proof

Proof. The fixed point of XXX under Galois group action Gal(Fqˉ/Fqm)\mathrm{Gal}(\bar{\mathbb{F}_{q}} /\mathbb{F}_{q^{m}})Gal(Fq​ˉ​/Fqm​) is exactly the Fqm\mathbb{F}_{q^{m}}Fqm​-points X(Fqm)X(\mathbb{F}_{q^{m}})X(Fqm​). So xxx is Fqm\mathbb{F}_{q^{m}}Fqm​-point if and only if it’s in the intersection of Γφ⋅Δ\Gamma_{\varphi}\cdot \DeltaΓφ​⋅Δ. It suffices to show each point has multiplicity 1. From the lemma, Γφ\Gamma_{\varphi}Γφ​ and Δ\DeltaΔ are all isomorphic to XXX, so they are nonsingular. For every point (φ(x),x)∈Γφ∩Δ(\varphi(x),x)\in \Gamma_{\varphi}\cap \Delta(φ(x),x)∈Γφ​∩Δ, the tangent space is the product of corresponding tangent space XXX. Note (dφ)x=0(d\varphi)_{x}=0(dφ)x​=0, Γφ\Gamma_{\varphi}Γφ​ and Δ\DeltaΔ intersect transversally, so each point has single multiplicity. ◻

A natural question is what is the degree of Frobenius for the projective curve XXX. The degree is a generic condition so we may focus on an affine open set. The case K(X)=Fq(t)K(X)=\mathbb{F}_{q}(t)K(X)=Fq​(t) is clear, the morphism is given by σ:Fq(t)→Fq(tq)\sigma: \mathbb{F}_{q}(t)\to \mathbb{F}_{q}(t^{q})σ:Fq​(t)→Fq​(tq). For the general case, K(X)K(X)K(X) is finite algebraic over Fq(t)\mathbb{F}_{q}(t)Fq​(t). Since the action on K(X)K(X)K(X) restrict on Fq(t)\mathbb{F}_{q}(t)Fq​(t) is the action on Fq(t)\mathbb{F}_{q}(t)Fq​(t), [K(X):Fq(t)]=[σK(X):σFq(t)][K(X):\mathbb{F}_{q}(t)]=[\sigma K(X):\sigma \mathbb{F}_{q}(t)][K(X):Fq​(t)]=[σK(X):σFq​(t)], and the results follow from the multiplicity of extension degree.

Hodge Index Theorem and Hasse Weil Bound

Theorem 9 (Hasse-Weil).

∣Nm−1−qm∣≤2gqm\left| N_{m}-1-q^{m} \right| \leq 2g\sqrt{q^{m}} ∣Nm​−1−qm∣≤2gqm​

To get the estimation of Γφ⋅Δ\Gamma_{\varphi}\cdot \DeltaΓφ​⋅Δ, we need the Hodge index theorem. Recall some facts in the intersection theory: Fix an very ample line sheaf OX×X(1)\mathcal{O}_{X\times X}(1)OX×X​(1), and denote the corresponding hyperplane section by HHH.

Lemma 10. Let L1\mathcal{L}_{1}L1​, L2\mathcal{L}_{2}L2​ be two line sheaves on a variety XXX. Then Hom(L1,L2)=0\mathrm{Hom}(\mathcal{L}_{1},\mathcal{L}_{2})=0Hom(L1​,L2​)=0 provided deg⁡L1>deg⁡L2\deg\mathcal{L}_{1}>\deg\mathcal{L}_{2}degL1​>degL2​.

Proof

Proof. Since rk(L1)=α2(L1)α2(OX)\mathrm{rk}(\mathcal{L}_{1})=\frac{\alpha_{2}(\mathcal{L}_{1})}{\alpha_{2}(\mathcal{O}_{X})}rk(L1​)=α2​(OX​)α2​(L1​)​ and rk(L2)=α2(L2)α2(OX)\mathrm{rk}(\mathcal{L}_{2})=\frac{\alpha_{2}(\mathcal{L}_{2})}{\alpha_{2}(\mathcal{O}_{X})}rk(L2​)=α2​(OX​)α2​(L2​)​, we have α2(L1)=α2(L2)\alpha_{2}(\mathcal{L}_{1})=\alpha_{2}(\mathcal{L}_{2})α2​(L1​)=α2​(L2​). The Hilbert polynomial P(L1)(n)<P(L2)(n)P(\mathcal{L}_{1})(n)<P(\mathcal{L}_{2})(n)P(L1​)(n)<P(L2​)(n). Suppose there is a morphism ψ:L1→L2\psi:\mathcal{L}_{1}\to \mathcal{L}_{2}ψ:L1​→L2​. Let K\mathcal{K}K, F\mathcal{F}F be the kernel and the image of ψ\psiψ, respectively.

We first show the support of F\mathcal{F}F is XXX. Assume there is a point x∈Xx\in Xx∈X that is not in the support of F\mathcal{F}F, since SuppF\mathrm{Supp}\mathcal{F}SuppF is closed, theres’s an open neighborhood UUU that has empty intersection with SuppF\mathrm{Supp}\mathcal{F}SuppF. We can choose an affine open set W=SpecAW=\mathrm{Spec}AW=SpecA that has nonempty intersection with X−UX-UX−U and UUU. Pick an nonzero global section sss supported on X−UX-UX−U and fff is an element in ideal which define W∩SuppsW\cap \mathrm{Supp}sW∩Supps. Then sss is zero in the localization of D(f)⊂WD(f)\subset WD(f)⊂W, so sfn=0sf^{n}=0sfn=0 for some nnn. However, sss is also in L1(W)\mathcal{L}_{1}(W)L1​(W), which is torsion-free, contradict to the above argument.

The Hilbert polynomial of F\mathcal{F}F is also a quadratic function. Since XXX is integral, the rank of F\mathcal{F}F is integer, and it is 1. Thus rk(K)=0\mathrm{rk}(\mathcal{K})=0rk(K)=0, which means α2(K)=0\alpha_{2}(\mathcal{K})=0α2​(K)=0, and dim⁡SuppK≤1\dim \mathrm{Supp}\mathcal{K}\leq 1dimSuppK≤1. Using a similar argument, we can prove that K=0\mathcal{K}=0K=0. Therefore, P(L1)(n)=P(F)(n)>P(L2)(n)P(\mathcal{L}_{1})(n)=P(\mathcal{F})(n)>P(\mathcal{L}_{2})(n)P(L1​)(n)=P(F)(n)>P(L2​)(n). This contradicts the fact that F\mathcal{F}F is a subsheaf of L2\mathcal{L}_{2}L2​. ◻

Lemma 11. Let {Di}\{D_{i}\}{Di​} be a set of divisor on X×XX\times XX×X with bounded degree. Then {h0(OX×X(Di))}\{h^{0}(\mathcal{O}_{X\times X}(D_{i}))\}{h0(OX×X​(Di​))} is bounded.

Proof

Proof. Assume deg⁡Di<m\deg D_{i}< mdegDi​<m. We first reduce to the case deg⁡Di\deg D_{i}degDi​ is a negative fixed number. For any divisor DDD in the family and the corresponding line sheaf OX(D)=L\mathcal{O}_{X}(D)=\mathcal{L}OX​(D)=L, consider the exact sequence

0→L(−m)→⋅sL→L∣C→00\to \mathcal{L}(-m)\xrightarrow{\cdot s} \mathcal{L}\to \mathcal{L}|_{C}\to 00→L(−m)⋅s​L→L∣C​→0

where sss is a regular section of L\mathcal{L}L and CCC is the support of sss, by Bertini theorem, such sss exists. Then h0(L)≤h0(L(−m))+h0(L∣C)h^{0}(\mathcal{L})\leq h^{0}(\mathcal{L}(-m))+h^{0}(\mathcal{L}|_{C})h0(L)≤h0(L(−m))+h0(L∣C​). Note that deg⁡C(L∣C)=deg⁡C(D∩C)=deg⁡X×X(D)\deg_{C}(\mathcal{L}|_{C})=\deg_{C}(D\cap C)=\deg_{X\times X}(D)degC​(L∣C​)=degC​(D∩C)=degX×X​(D). The genus gCg_{C}gC​ is independent on the choice of CCC, and is given by the adjunction formula gC=1+12(K⋅Em+Em⋅Em)g_{C}=1+\frac{1}{2}(K\cdot E_{m} +E_{m}\cdot E_{m})gC​=1+21​(K⋅Em​+Em​⋅Em​) where EmE_{m}Em​ is the divisor corresponding to O(m)\mathcal{O}(m)O(m) and therefore bounded.

If deg⁡C(L∣C)>2g−2\deg_{C}(\mathcal{L}|_{C})>2g-2degC​(L∣C​)>2g−2, then h0(L∣C)=deg⁡C(L∣C)+1−g≤m+1−gh^{0}(\mathcal{L}|_{C})=\deg_{C}(\mathcal{L}|_{C})+1-g\leq m+1-gh0(L∣C​)=degC​(L∣C​)+1−g≤m+1−g.

If deg⁡C(L∣C)≤2g−2\deg_{C}(\mathcal{L}|_{C})\leq 2g-2degC​(L∣C​)≤2g−2, then h0(L∣C)≤h0(L∣C(2g−1−m))=gh^{0}(\mathcal{L}|_{C})\leq h^{0}(\mathcal{L}|_{C}(2g-1-m))=gh0(L∣C​)≤h0(L∣C​(2g−1−m))=g.

Then we have h0(L∣C)h^{0}(\mathcal{L}|_{C})h0(L∣C​) bounded and we reduce to the case deg⁡(Di)\deg(D_{i})deg(Di​) is negative constant by twisting a small number. Since a global section in h0(OX(D))h^{0}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(D))h0(OX​(D)) will induce a morphism from OX\mathcal{O}_{X}OX​ to OX(D)\mathcal{O}_{X}(D)OX​(D), by above lemma, OX(Di)\mathcal{O}_{X}(D_{i})OX​(Di​) has no global sections. This finishes the proof. ◻

Theorem 12 (Hodge Index Theorem). Let DDD be a divisor on X×XX\times XX×X. If deg⁡(D)=0\deg (D)=0deg(D)=0, then D⋅D<0D\cdot D<0D⋅D<0.

Proof

Proof. By above lemma, {h0(nD)}\{h^{0}(nD)\}{h0(nD)} and {h0(K−nD)}\{h^{0}(K-nD)\}{h0(K−nD)} are all bounded. Using Riemann-Roch theorem on surface,

h0(nD)−h1(nD)+h0(K−nD)=12nD(nD−K)+1+pah^{0}(nD)-h^{1}(nD)+h^{0}(K-nD)=\frac{1}{2}nD(nD-K)+1+p_{a}h0(nD)−h1(nD)+h0(K−nD)=21​nD(nD−K)+1+pa​

For large nnn, left hand side of the equation is negative, so n2D⋅D<0n^{2}D\cdot D<0n2D⋅D<0. ◻

For any automorphism f:X→Xf:X\to Xf:X→X, we compute the self intersection number of Γf\Gamma_{f}Γf​. Let deg⁡(f)=d\deg(f)=ddeg(f)=d. Using the adjunction formula, Γf⋅(Γf+K)=2g−2\Gamma_{f}\cdot (\Gamma_{f}+K)=2g-2Γf​⋅(Γf​+K)=2g−2. Since ωX×X=p1∗ωX⊗p2∗ωX\omega_{X\times X}=p_{1}^{*}\omega_{X}\otimes p_{2}^{*}\omega_{X}ωX×X​=p1∗​ωX​⊗p2∗​ωX​, KX×X=p1∗KX+p2∗KXK_{X\times X}=p_{1}^{*}K_{X}+p_{2}^{*}K_{X}KX×X​=p1∗​KX​+p2∗​KX​. Γf⋅p1∗KX\Gamma_{f}\cdot p_{1}^{*}K_{X}Γf​⋅p1∗​KX​ is the same as the deg⁡Γf(p1∗ωX⊗OΓf)=deg⁡Γf(Γf∗p1∗ωX)\deg_{\Gamma_{f}}(p_{1}^{*}\omega_{X}\otimes \mathcal{O}_{\Gamma_{f}})=\deg_{\Gamma_{f}}(\Gamma_{f}^{*}p_{1}^{*}\omega_{X})degΓf​​(p1∗​ωX​⊗OΓf​​)=degΓf​​(Γf∗​p1∗​ωX​), since p1∘Γf=fp_{1}\circ \Gamma_{f}=fp1​∘Γf​=f, it is also the same as deg⁡Γf(f∗ωX)=deg⁡(f)deg⁡(ωX)=d(2g−2)\deg_{\Gamma_{f}}(f^{*}\omega_{X})=\deg (f)\deg(\omega_{X})=d(2g-2)degΓf​​(f∗ωX​)=deg(f)deg(ωX​)=d(2g−2). Similarly, Γf⋅p2∗KX=2g−2\Gamma_{f}\cdot p_{2}^{*}K_{X}=2g-2Γf​⋅p2∗​KX​=2g−2. So Γf⋅Γf=−d(2g−2)\Gamma_{f}\cdot \Gamma_{f}=-d(2g-2)Γf​⋅Γf​=−d(2g−2).

Let f=idf=idf=id, the self intersection number Δ⋅Δ=2−2g\Delta\cdot \Delta=2-2gΔ⋅Δ=2−2g.

Let d1(D)=D⋅(P×X)d_{1}(D)=D\cdot (P\times X)d1​(D)=D⋅(P×X) and d2(D)=D⋅(X×P′)d_{2}(D)=D\cdot (X\times P')d2​(D)=D⋅(X×P′) for some PPP, P′P'P′ closed points in XXX. We can choose the degree of PPP and P′P'P′ to be 1.

Theorem 13. $$D\cdot D\leq 2d_{1}(D)d_{2}(D)$$

Proof

Proposition 14. Let XXX be a smooth projective varitey. Then

ZX(t)=∏x closed11−tdeg⁡(x).Z_{X}(t)=\prod_{x \text{ closed}}\frac{1}{1-t^{\deg(x)}}. ZX​(t)=x closed∏​1−tdeg(x)1​.

Proof

Proof. Set ndn_{d}nd​ be the number of closed points with degree ddd in XXX. By Proposition 4,

log⁡(ZX(t))=∑m≥1Nmmtm=∑m≥1∑d∣mnd⋅dmtm=∑d≥1nd∑etdee=∑d≥1−ndlog⁡(1−td).\begin{aligned} \log(Z_{X}(t))&=\sum_{m\geq 1}\frac{N_{m}}{m}t^{m}=\sum_{m\geq 1}\sum_{d\mid m}\frac{n_{d}\cdot d}{m}t^{m}\\ &= \sum_{d\geq 1}n_{d}\sum_{e} \frac{t^{de}}{e}\\ &=\sum_{d\geq 1}-n_{d}\log(1-t^{d}).\end{aligned}log(ZX​(t))​=m≥1∑​mNm​​tm=m≥1∑​d∣m∑​mnd​⋅d​tm=d≥1∑​nd​e∑​etde​=d≥1∑​−nd​log(1−td).​

We therefore have the desired formula. ◻

For curve XXX, the degree of divisor ∑xi closedaixi\sum\limits_{x_{i} \text{ closed}} a_{i} x_{i}xi​ closed∑​ai​xi​ can be realized as ∑iaideg⁡(xi)\sum_{i}a_{i}\deg(x_{i})∑i​ai​deg(xi​). So once we expand ZX(t)=∏x closed∑i=0∞ti⋅deg⁡(x)Z_{X}(t)=\prod\limits_{x\text{ closed}}\sum_{i=0}^{\infty}t^{i\cdot \deg(x)}ZX​(t)=x closed∏​∑i=0∞​ti⋅deg(x), it immediately follows that ZX(t)=∑D effectivetdeg⁡(D)Z_{X}(t)=\sum\limits_{D\text{ effective}}t^{\deg(D)}ZX​(t)=D effective∑​tdeg(D) for Weil divisors.

The degree map deg⁡:Pic(X)→Z\deg:\mathop{\mathrm{Pic}}(X)\to \mathbb{Z}deg:Pic(X)→Z is a group homomorphism, so we may write its image as eZe\mathbb{Z}eZ.
